content: Ecoregion on the Malay Peninsula The **Peninsular Malaysian rain forests** is an [ecoregion](/wiki/Ecoregion) on the [Malay Peninsula](/wiki/Malay_Peninsula) and adjacent islands. It is in the [tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests](/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests) [biome](/wiki/Biome). ## Geography The ecoregion covers most of the southern [Malay Peninsula](/wiki/Malay_Peninsula) in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and southern [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand), and extends southwards to [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), the [Riau Archipelago](/wiki/Riau_Archipelago), and [Lingga Islands](/wiki/Lingga_Islands), and east to the [Anamba Islands](/wiki/Anamba_Islands). The peninsula is fringed with mangroves, including the [Indochina mangroves](/wiki/Indochina_mangroves) on the eastern shore, and the [Myanmar coast mangroves](/wiki/Myanmar_coast_mangroves) on the western shore. The ecologically distinct [Peninsular Malaysian peat swamp forests](/wiki/Peninsular_Malaysian_peat_swamp_forests) ecoregion are found in waterlogged lowlands on the east and west sides of the peninsula. The [Titiwangsa Mountains](/wiki/Titiwangsa_Mountains) form the mountainous backbone of the peninsula, and the range's higher elevations are home to the [Peninsular Malaysian montane rain forests](/wiki/Peninsular_Malaysian_montane_rain_forests) ecoregion. ## Flora The predominant trees are [dipterocarps](/wiki/Dipterocarp), including species of *[Anisoptera](/wiki/Anisoptera), [Dipterocarpus](/wiki/Dipterocarpus), [Dryobalanops](/wiki/Dryobalanops), [Hopea](/wiki/Hopea)*, and *[Shorea](/wiki/Shorea)*. The forests are home to over 15,000 tree species, and trees of the families [Burseraceae](/wiki/Burseraceae) and [Sapotaceae](/wiki/Sapotaceae) are also common. Trees form a canopy 24-36 meters high, with emergent trees rising up 45 meters or more. The tallest emergent is *[Koompassia excelsa](/wiki/Koompassia_excelsa)*, known as tualang, which can grow more than 76 meters high. ## Fauna The ecoregion home to 195 mammal species, including several large and endangered species – [Asian elephant](/wiki/Asian_elephant) (*Elephas maximus*), [gaur](/wiki/Gaur) (*Bos gaurus*), [tiger](/wiki/Tiger) (*Panthera tigris*), [Malayan tapir](/wiki/Malayan_tapir) (*Tapirus indicus*), and [clouded leopard](/wiki/Clouded_leopard) (*Neofelis nebulosa*). The [Sumatran rhinoceros](/wiki/Sumatran_rhinoceros) (*Dicerorhinus sumatrensis*) once inhabited the forests, but Malaysia's last rhinoceroses died in 2019, and the species' few remaining members survive only in [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra). ## Conservation A 2017 assessment found that 20,113 km2, or 16%, of the ecoregion is in [protected areas](/wiki/Protected_area). Protected areas in the ecoregion include [Endau Rompin National Park](/wiki/Endau_Rompin_National_Park) (1191.59 km²), Endau-Kota Tinggi (West) Wildlife Reserve (805.49 km²), Endau-Kota Tinggi (East) Wildlife Reserve (106.5 km²), Krau Wildlife Reserve (623.96 km²), Mersin Wildlife Reserve (74.13 km²), and [Ulu Muda Wildlife Reserve](/wiki/Ulu_Muda_Wildlife_Reserve) (1152.57 km²). [Taman Negara National Park](/wiki/Taman_Negara_National_Park) (4524.54 km²) and [Royal Belum State Park](/wiki/Royal_Belum_State_Park) (2072.0 km²) include portions of the ecoregion along with portions of the Peninsular Malaysian montane rain forests. - Media related to Peninsular Malaysian Rainforests Ecoregion at Wikimedia Commons - "Peninsular Malaysian rain forests". *Terrestrial Ecoregions*. World Wildlife Fund.
title: Peninsular Malaysian rain forests
